statements.name: PROC REPORT
statements.description: Combines features of the PRINT, MEANS, and TABULATE procedures with features of the DATA step in a single report-writing tool that can produce a variety of reports.

arguments.name: BYPAGENO=
arguments.description: resets the page number between BY groups.

arguments.name: CAPTION=
arguments.description: specifies a caption text string to add before each table. If no string is specified, the caption defaults to the text specified by the CONTENTS= option.

arguments.name: #BYLINE
arguments.description: substitutes the entire BY line without leading or trailing blanks for #BYLINE in the text string. The BY line uses the format variable-name=value.

arguments.name: #BYVAL
arguments.description: substitutes the current value of the specified BY variable for #BYVAL in the text string.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAL2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAL(YEAR) specifies the BY variable, YEAR. Variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: #BYVAR
arguments.description: substitutes the name of the BY-variable or the label associated with the variable (whatever the BY line would normally display) for #BYVAR in the text string.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAR2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAR(SITES) specifies the BY variable, SITES. Variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: CENTER
arguments.description: specifies whether to center or left-justify the report and summary text.

arguments.name: NOCENTER
arguments.description: specifies whether to center or left-justify the report and summary text.

arguments.name: COMPLETECOLS
arguments.description: creates all possible combinations of the across variable values.

arguments.name: NOCOMPLETECOLS
arguments.description: creates all possible combinations of the across variable values.

arguments.name: COMPLETEROWS
arguments.description: creates all possible combinations of the group variable values.

arguments.name: NOCOMPLETEROWS
arguments.description: creates all possible combinations of the group variable values.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: specifies text for the table of contents entry for the output.

arguments.name: #BYLINE
arguments.description: substitutes the entire BY line without leading or trailing blanks for #BYLINE in the text string. The BY line uses the format variable-name=value.

arguments.name: #BYVAL
arguments.description: substitutes the current value of the specified BY variable for #BYVAL in the text string.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAL2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAL(YEAR) specifies the BY variable, YEAR. Variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: #BYVAR
arguments.description: substitutes the name of the BY-variable or the label associated with the variable (whatever the BY line would normally display) for #BYVAR in the text string.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies a variable by its position in the BY statement. For example, #BYVAR2 specifies the second variable in the BY statement.

arguments.name: BY-variable-name
arguments.description: specifies a variable from the BY statement by its name. For example, #BYVAR(SITES) specifies the BY variable, SITES. Variable-name is not case sensitive.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set.

arguments.name: EXCLNPWGT
arguments.description: excludes observations with nonpositive weight values from the analysis.

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: writes to the SAS log the PROC REPORT code that creates the current report.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: considers missing values as valid values for group, order, or across variables.

arguments.name: NAMED
arguments.description: writes name= in front of each value in the report, where name= is the column heading for the value.

arguments.name: NOALIAS
arguments.description: uses a report that was created before compute blocks required aliases.

arguments.name: NOEXEC
arguments.description: suppresses the building of the report.

arguments.name: NOHEADER
arguments.description: suppresses column headings.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set.

arguments.name: OUTREPT=
arguments.description: stores in the specified catalog the report definition that is defined by the PROC REPORT step that you submit.

arguments.name: QMARKERS=
arguments.description: specifies the sample size to use for the P2 quantile estimation method.

arguments.name: QMETHOD=
arguments.description: specifies the quantile estimation method.

arguments.name: OS
arguments.description: uses order statistics. PROC UNIVARIATE uses this technique.

arguments.name: P2
arguments.description: uses the P2 method to approximate the quantile.

arguments.name: QNTLDEF=
arguments.description: specifies the mathematical definition to calculate quantiles.

arguments.name: REPORT=
arguments.description: specifies the report definition to use.

arguments.name: SHOWALL
arguments.description: overrides options in the DEFINE statement that suppress the display of a column.

arguments.name: SPANROWS
arguments.description: specifies that a single cell occupies the column in all the rows for which the value is the same.

arguments.name: SPLIT=
arguments.description: specifies the split character.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies one or more style overrides to use for different parts of the report.

arguments.name: location
arguments.description: identifies the part of the report that the STYLE= option affects. The following table shows what parts of a report are affected by values of location.

arguments.name: style-element-name
arguments.description: is the name of a style element that is part of an ODS style template. SAS provides some style templates. Users can create their own style templates with the TEMPLATE procedure. See

arguments.name: style-attribute-name
arguments.description: specifies the attribute to change. For a list of the commonly used style attributes that you can set with the STYLE= option in PROC PRINT, PROC TABULATE, and PROC REPORT, see .

arguments.name: style-attribute-value
arguments.description: specifies a value for the attribute. Each attribute has a different set of valid values. A SAS format can also be used as an attribute value for conditional formatting.

arguments.name: THREADS
arguments.description: overrides the SAS system option THREADS | NOTHREADS.

arguments.name: NOTHREADS
arguments.description: overrides the SAS system option THREADS | NOTHREADS.

arguments.name: VARDEF=
arguments.description: specifies the divisor to use in the calculation of variances.

arguments.name: DF
arguments.description: Degrees of freedom

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Number of observations

arguments.name: WDF
arguments.description: Sum of weights minus one

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: Sum of weights

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Associates a format, informat, label, and length with one or more variables.

arguments.name: variable-list
arguments.description: names the variables that you want to associate with the attributes.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: associates a format with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: INFORMAT=
arguments.description: associates an informat with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: associates a label with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE=
arguments.description: specifies whether character variables can be transcoded. Use TRANSCODE=NO to suppress transcoding. Variables with TRANSCODE=NO are not returned.

statements.name: BREAK
statements.description: Produces a default summary at a break (a change in the value of a group or order variable). The information in a summary applies to a set of observations. The observations share a unique combination of values for the break variable and all other group or order variables to the left of the break variable in the report.

arguments.name: AFTER
arguments.description: places the break lines immediately after the last row of each set of rows that have the same value for the break variable.

arguments.name: BEFORE
arguments.description: places the break lines immediately before the first row of each set of rows that have the same value for the break variable.

arguments.name: break-variable
arguments.description: is a group or order variable. The REPORT procedure writes break lines each time the value of this variable changes.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: specifies the link text used in the table of contents.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: starts a new page after the last break line.

arguments.name: STYLE
arguments.description: specifies a style override to use for default summary lines, customized summary lines or both.

arguments.name: SUMMARIZE
arguments.description: writes a summary line in each group of break lines.

arguments.name: SUPPRESS
arguments.description: suppresses the printing of the value of the break variable in the summary line and of any underlining or overlining in the break lines in the column containing the break variable.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Orders the output according to the BY groups.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variable that the procedure uses to form BY groups. You can specify more than one variable. If you do not use the NOTSORTED option in the BY statement, then either the observations in the data set must be sorted by all the variables that you specify, or they must be indexed appropriately. Variables in a BY statement are called BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order. The observations are grouped in another way (for example, chronological order).

statements.name: CALL DEFINE
statements.description: Sets the value of an attribute for a particular column in the current row. Only the FORMAT, URL, URLBP, and URLP attributes have an effect. The STYLE= and URL attributes are effective only when you are using ODS to create output.

arguments.name: column-id
arguments.description: specifies a column name or a column number (that is, the position of the column from the left edge of the report). A column ID can be one of the following: • a character literal (in quotation marks) that is the column name • a character expression that resolves to the column name • a numeric literal that is the column number • a numeric expression that resolves to the column number • a name of the form '_Cn_', where n is the column number • the automatic variable _COL_, which identifies the column that contains the report item that the compute block is attached to

arguments.name: _ROW_
arguments.description: is an automatic variable that indicates the entire current row.

arguments.name: attribute-name
arguments.description: is the attribute to define. For attribute names, refer to .

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: sets the value for the attribute. For values for each attribute, refer to .

statements.name: COLUMN
statements.description: Describes the arrangement of all columns and of headings that span more than one column.

arguments.name: report-item
arguments.description: identifies items that each form a column in the report.

arguments.name: report-item-1,
arguments.description: identifies report items that collectively determine the contents of the column or columns. These items are said to be stacked in the report because each item generates a heading, and the headings are stacked one above the other. The heading for the leftmost item is on top. If one of the items is an analysis variable, a computed variable, a group variable, or a statistic, then its values fill the cells in that part of the report. Otherwise, PROC REPORT fills the cells with frequency counts.

arguments.name: header
arguments.description: is a string of characters that spans one or more columns in the report. PROC REPORT prints each heading on a separate line. You can use split characters in a heading to split one heading over multiple lines. See the discussion of SPLIT=.

arguments.name: report-item
arguments.description: specifies the columns to span.

arguments.name: report-item=
arguments.description: specifies an alias for a report item. You can use the same report item more than once in a COLUMN statement. However, you can use only one DEFINE statement for any given name. (The DEFINE statement designates characteristics such as formats and customized column headings. If you omit a DEFINE statement for an item, then the REPORT procedure uses defaults.) Assigning an alias in the COLUMN statement does not by itself alter the report. However, it does enable you to use separate DEFINE statements for each occurrence of a variable or statistic.

statements.name: COMPUTE
statements.description: Starts a compute block containing one or more programming statements that PROC REPORT executes as it builds the report.

arguments.name: AFTER
arguments.description: executes the compute block at a break in one of the following places: • immediately after the last row of a set of rows that have the same value for the variable that you specify as target or, if there is a default summary on that variable, immediately after the creation of the preliminary summary line. • at the end of the report if you omit a target.

arguments.name: BEFORE
arguments.description: executes the compute block at a break in one of the following places: • immediately before the first row of a set of rows that have the same value for the variable that you specify as target or, if there is a default summary on that variable, immediately after the creation of the preliminary summary line. • immediately before the first detail row if you omit a target.

arguments.name: report-item
arguments.description: specifies a data set variable, a computed variable, or a statistic to associate the compute block with. You must include the report item in the COLUMN statement. If the item is a computed variable, then you must include a DEFINE statement for it.

arguments.name: break-variable
arguments.description: is a group or order variable.

arguments.name: _PAGE_
arguments.description: justification controls the placement of text and values. It can be one of the following:

arguments.name: CENTER
arguments.description: centers each line that the compute block writes.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: left-justifies each line that the compute block writes.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: right-justifies each line that the compute block writes.

arguments.name: CHARACTER
arguments.description: specifies that the computed variable is a character variable. If you do not specify a length, then the variable's length is 8.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of a computed character variable.

arguments.name: STYLE
arguments.description: specifies the style to use for the text that is created by any LINE statements in this compute block.

statements.name: DEFINE
statements.description: Describes how to use and display a report item.

arguments.name: report-item
arguments.description:
specifies the name or alias (established in the COLUMN statement) of the data set variable, computed variable, or statistic to define. The following are types of names that can be used for report-item:
• a SAS identifier (determined by the VALIDVARNAME option)
• a name literal
•  a numbered range list
• a name range list
• a special name list
• a name prefix list
• a statistic

arguments.name: ACROSS
arguments.description: defines the item, which must be a data set variable, as an across variable.

arguments.name: ANALYSIS
arguments.description: defines the item, which must be a data set variable, as an analysis variable.

arguments.name: CENTER
arguments.description: centers the formatted values of the report item within the column width and center the column heading over the values.

arguments.name: column-header
arguments.description: defines the column heading for the report item.

arguments.name: COMPUTED
arguments.description: defines the item as a computed variable.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: creates a link in the table of contents.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: reverses the order in which PROC REPORT displays rows or values of a group, order, or across variable.

arguments.name: DISPLAY
arguments.description: defines the item, which must be a data set variable, as a display variable.

arguments.name: EXCLUSIVE
arguments.description: excludes all combinations of the item that are not found in the preloaded range of user-defined formats.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: assigns a SAS or user-defined format to the item.

arguments.name: GROUP
arguments.description: defines the item, which must be a data set variable, as a group variable.

arguments.name: ID
arguments.description: specifies that the item that you are defining is an ID variable.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: left-justifies the formatted values of the report item within the column width and left-justifies the column headings over the values.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: considers missing values as valid values for the item.

arguments.name: MLF
arguments.description: enables PROC REPORT to use the format label or labels to create subgroup combinations that have multilabel formats.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: suppresses the display of the report item.

arguments.name: NOZERO
arguments.description: suppresses the display of the report item if its values are all zero or missing.

arguments.name: ORDER
arguments.description: defines the item, which must be a data set variable, as an order variable.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: orders the values of a group, order, or across variable according to the specified order.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: orders values according to their order in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: orders values by their formatted (external) values. If no format has been assigned to a class variable, then the default format, BEST12., is used.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: orders values by ascending frequency count.

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order that PROC SORT would yield. This order is operating environment-dependent. This sort sequence is particularly useful for displaying dates chronologically.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: inserts a page break just before printing the first column containing values of the report item.

arguments.name: PRELOADFMT
arguments.description: specifies that all formats are preloaded for the item.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: right-justifies the formatted values of the report item within the column width and right-justifies the column headings over the values.

arguments.name: statistic
arguments.description: associates a statistic with an analysis variable.

arguments.name: STYLE
arguments.description: specifies a style element (for the Output Delivery System) for the report item.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies a numeric variable whose values weight the value of the analysis variable.

statements.name: ENDCOMP
statements.description: Marks the end of one or more programming statements that PROC REPORT executes as it builds the report.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names one or more variables for SAS to associate with a format. You must specify at least one variable.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: specifies the format that is listed for writing the values of the variables.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: Treats observations as if they appear multiple times in the input data set.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies a numeric variable whose value represents the frequency of the observation. If you use the FREQ statement, then the procedure assumes that each observation represents n observations, where n is the value of variable. If n is not an integer, then SAS truncates it. If n is less than 1 or is missing, then the procedure does not use that observation to calculate statistics.

arguments.name: text-string
arguments.description: specifies a label of up to 256 bytes.
removes a label from a variable. Enclose a single blank space in quotation marks to remove an existing label. You can remove labels from multiple variables in a single LABEL statement:

statements.name: LINE
statements.description: Provides a subset of the features of the PUT statement for writing customized summaries.

arguments.name: item
arguments.description: is the name of a data set variable, a computed variable, or a statistic in the report. For information about referencing report items, see .

arguments.name: item-format
arguments.description: is a SAS format or user-defined format. You must specify a format for each item.

arguments.name: 'character-string
arguments.description: specifies a string of text to display. When the string is a blank and nothing else is in specification(s), PROC REPORT prints a blank line.

arguments.name: number-of-repetitions*'character-string
arguments.description: specifies a character string and the number of times to repeat it.

statements.name: RBREAK
statements.description: Produces a default summary at the beginning or end of a report or at the beginning or end of each BY group.

arguments.name: AFTER
arguments.description: places the break lines at the end of the report.

arguments.name: BEFORE
arguments.description: places the break lines at the beginning of the report.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: specifies the link text used in the table of contents.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: starts a new page after the last break line of a break located at the beginning of the report.

arguments.name: STYLE
arguments.description: specifies a style element (for the Output Delivery System) for default summary lines, customized summary lines, or both.

arguments.name: SUMMARIZE
arguments.description: includes a summary line as one of the break lines.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: Specifies weights for analysis variables in the statistical calculations.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies a numeric variable whose values weight the values of the analysis variables. The value of the variable does not have to be an integer.

statements.name: WHERE
statements.description: Subsets the input data set by specifying certain conditions that each observation must meet before it is available for processing.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that generally consists of a sequence of operands and operators.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.
